Review Title: Jetavanarama stupa is NOT Abhagiri Stupa.  This is different.

Review Text: ‚Ä¢	The next morning at around 7:30, we explored the revered Abhayagiriya Stupa and its extensive archaeological site, covering approximately 200 hectares . Workers were already busy on-site amidst this vast ancient temple complex. This is an indescribably large ancient temple complex. ‚Ä¢	From the moment we commenced trekking through the sunlit pathways amply covered by huge shady trees, I was captivated by the rich history of ancient Sri Lanka. Every direction revealed the profound legacy embedded in each stone of this sacred area. The whispers of centuries past echoed through rustling leaves, reflecting the cultural heritage that flourished here, a monumental testament to the architectural excellence of a bygone era. ‚Ä¢	As I stood in its shadow these are, a hidden world of architectural marvels and cultural treasures waiting to be unearthed. The remnants of the former weather beaten monasteries for more than 1000 of years though still convey a sense of grandeur. The intricate carvings and sturdy stonework tell tales of devotion and artistry, urging us to delve deeper into the narrative woven into the very fabric of the ruins. ‚Ä¢	Abhayagiriya is one of the most captivating religious and archaeo logical sites in Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka's ancient capital. The complex remains largely unexplored,with only about a third of the existing structures uncovered. In addition to the iconic massive stupa, the site features bedeviled by picturesque ruins overgrown with tangled undergrowth.

Review Title: Jethawanaramaya: A Monumental Stupa of Spiritual and Architectural Grandeur ‚Äì A Tour Guide‚Äôs Perspective
Review Text: Review of Jethawanaramaya from a Tour Guide‚Äôs Perspective As a tour guide, visiting **Jethawanaramaya** in Anuradhapura is always an awe-inspiring experience for both my guests and myself. This ancient stupa, one of the largest in the world, stands as a monumental reminder of Sri Lanka‚Äôs rich Buddhist heritage and the incredible engineering feats of the ancient Sinhalese civilization. Historical Significance Jethawanaramaya was constructed by King Mahasena in the 3rd century AD, and its original height is said to have reached over 120 meters, making it one of the tallest man-made structures of its time. It was built on the site where Mahinda Thera, the monk who introduced Buddhism to Sri Lanka, resided. When I share these details with visitors, they often express surprise at how advanced the ancient Sri Lankan civilization was, particularly in terms of construction and religious devotion. Architectural Marvel The sheer scale of the stupa is what usually leaves visitors speechless. Built entirely of bricks, it is said that over 93 million bricks were used to complete this towering structure. The stupendous size of Jethawanaramaya is not just a display of religious devotion but also a testament to the architectural brilliance of ancient Sri Lanka. As I guide guests around the stupa, I like to highlight the craftsmanship of the brickwork and the symmetry of the structure, which are still well-preserved despite being centuries old. Spiritual Atmosphere Beyond its architectural grandeur, Jethawanaramaya offers a peaceful and spiritual ambiance. The site is often filled with pilgrims, making offerings and chanting prayers, which enhances the sacred atmosphere. I always encourage my guests to take a moment to absorb the tranquility of the surroundings, as it offers a deeper connection to the spiritual history of the place. For many, the quiet reflection at the base of the stupa becomes a cherished moment in their journey through Sri Lanka. *

The Jetavanaramaya is a stupa located in the ruins of Jetavana in the sacred world heritage city of Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka. Mahasena of Anuradhapura (273‚Äì301) initiated the construction of the stupa following the destruction of the mahavihara. His son Maghavanna I completed the construction of the stupa. it is also significant in recorded history as one of the tallest structures in the ancient world and the second tallest non-pyramidal buildings after Pharos (lighthouse) of Alexandria; the height of the stupa is 400 feet, making it the tallest stupa in the ancient world. The structure is no longer the tallest, but it is still the largest, with a base-area of 2,508,000 sq ft. Approximately 93.3 million baked bricks were used in its construction. JETAVANA DAGOBA The Jetavana Dagoba (Stupa), a UNESCO world heritage site, is the highest brick-built Dagobah in the world, founded by King Mahasena (276-303 AC) upon Mahayana Buddhism, on the ruins of an old monatery. When built with over 93 million bricks in 27 years, it was the third tallest structure in the world after two pyramids of Khufu & Khafra in Giza, Cairo (Egypt). Originally its height was 397 feet and it was erected on land measuring 8 acres. Its diameter was more than 330 feet. Today it is 230 feet high and restoration work is in progress. Before wearing down of its pinnacle, erosion of ground and burial of the base, its height was 400 feet. The Jetavana monastery in its hey days housed bout 3000 monks. It is one of the sixteen most sacred cultural destinations in Anuradhapura.

This Dagoba is the largest in Sri-Lanka, it was under renovation for a very  long time, most of it is over & the dagoba looks nice although only the bricks are there. This temple is full of history, so a Guide or Guide book is necessary if you are interested in the history, as language is a problem. Be appropriately dressed as a mark of respect to Buddhism, even if its very hot. The best time to visit is early morning till about 12 pm & evening after about 4 p.m.
in anuradapura affter enter world heritage site you can see this amizing very big budist sthupa or dagoba. row mateerial is millions of briks.affter visite anuradapura dont miss this site

This is located in the Anuradhapura sacred city, giving grand look to Anuradhapura.This is 400 feet high tallest Buddhist brick monument in the world's history and constructed in 3rd century AD by King Mahasen and later his son completed it. They have used more than 90 million bricks to build this solidly covered stupa.According to historical sources,we believe that Lord Buddha's belt was enshrined here.
An amazing level of architectural brilliance. 120 metres high made from bricks and hundreds of years old. In the process of being restored. Important Buddhist monument.

This Dagoba was built in 3rd century by king Mahasena, It was the third largest structure in the world that time (first and second being Egyptian pyramids). In addition that was the first ever largest brick structure built by man. It has been estimated over 90 million bricks were used for the project; enough bricks to build 3m high wall from London to Edinburgh. The original height estimated at 120 present day it is only 70m tall. You will not wast your time visiting this place as this is only a single place in an ancient city.
Awesome and worth the trek!  But be-warned, wear simple footwear as you will need to remove both shoes and hats when going near the stupas or any sacred sites, of which there are many.

The stupa is located in the Southern part of the Anuradhapura site. It is original because it is not a traditional white stupa, it is a brick one. When it was built (3rd century) it was the third tallest structure in the world after the pyramids in Egypt!

Jethawanaramaya is the largest stupa in the area and probably the largest in Sri Lanka itself. Our guide mentioned that this is the largest brick structure in the world. Irrespective of the superlatives, this is a magnificent structure. The size does impress you. There is a very long history around this Stupa. The Stupa was built by King Mahasena ( 3rd Century AD) and was renovated and developed by successive kings. At the time of King Parakaramabahu the Great ( 10th Century) the Stupa was around 120mtrs high.Currently the Stupa stands at 73 mtrs till the broken Spire. We visited in the morning time and there were hardly any one at the stupa. There wasn't any one to check the tickets too.

I preferred this to the Ruwanwelisseya Dagoba as it is far less crowded and appears a little forgotten compared to its rival, but the greater proximity to the trees and the additional troops of monkeys drives a feeling of awe and exoticism to the stupa.   This is amplified further by the sheer size and worn exterior, and with there being fewer visitors to distract you its somewhere you can take it all in and enjoy in your own time.

The biggest stupa in Sri Lanka. You really feel dwarfed in its presence. The Jethawanarama stupa has not been plastered or painted; making it naturally majestic. The vast area at the base of the stupa is very serene. This place of worship isn't as crowded as places like Sri Maha Bodhi or Ruwanwaliseya Stupa. At night the base of the stupa has a calming ambience. This is a place I visit everytime I am in Anuradhapura. Definitely worth a visit.

This stupa is more than 120 metres high and quite incredible to look at even from a distance given that it contains so many bricks. It shows a level of technological sophistication existed hundreds of years ago. I observed many monkeys in and around this stupa.
Very Good.  The Stupa is one of the oldest in Sri-lanka and a place of importance to Buddhists. The building is old and very tall for the date it was built.

I do not suggest a driver.  I prefer solo.  Try not to engage the locals  The tuk-tuk driver tried to get me to pay 2000 rupees for the day.  I enjoyed the pictures and the hike and the history.  As I learned in Nepal and Kenya, always barter and start REAL small.

The ancient wisdom of building dome shape from the unknown bare hands method always a big wow to witness! One of largest stupa with widest base structures, believed to host as large as 10,000 monks during that time.

Definitely worth to be seen. Stupas are where the ashes of Buddhist monks are kept. You can walk around it but barefoot only. Many monkeys can be seen on the stupa as well. The stupa is 122m. high so it's quite impressive.
Again whole Anuradhapura Sri Lanka trip gave us very pleasant feeling , nice place to explore and also to spend days in a great historical site.

All I know is that I keep wondering what happened to the top of the stupa itself as out of the three giant stupas in Anuradhapura it is the only one missing a chunk.  Also out of the three stupas this one seemed to be the most tranquil and the least visited (very few people there when I visited).  I say go and take a walk around.  There were also a lot of monkeys at this compound and they made for great entertainment.

This is one of the greatest attractions of the ancient sacred city of Anuradhapura and is a 'must' to see. One of the many wonderful things about the Anuradhapura experience is the immense variety of structures to be seen and this huge building of Jethawanaramaya is very different from others because of its construction from brick. It is quite amazing how the brickwork was done. If one purchases a ticket for the main attractions of Anuradhapura, this stupa is included in the price. As with all of the sacred places, shoes must be removed before entering and appropriate clothing worn.

One of the very important monument of the Sri Lankan early kingdoms and buddhism history! Don't miss it! Don't forget, hat and shoes forbidden inside the sacred area. You will need sun protection cream, and exchange socks is very practical. The reason not just the dirty floor (these places wasn't really dirty), very often the stone very hot without shoes. I recommend you, before the visit you must read some historical fact about this place, will be interesting the visit!
A wonderful structure which must be visited whilst in Anuradhapura. It is quite different to the other stupas in the area and the brickwork is impressive. It is included in the main ticket.
Amazing that this massive, apparently younger structure is so old - and the brickwork is really impressive.
This was my favourite of all the dagoba's we visited in Anuradhapura, just huge, incredible and awe inspiring and still one of the largest/tallest brick built structures from the ancient world.

This is the most incredible structure. One can only gaze in awe and wonder how on earth did they manage to construct it. Also a peaceful place (I guess we were there in the off season) to wander around without getting hassled by anyone.

Traveling in Sri Lanka you can get a bit "Stupa'd out". What added to the magic was the black faced monkeys (so much friendlier and cuter then the white faced ones), climbing and running around the Stupa. It is dry season so was very hot. Take a lot of water with you.

We felt like this is the most significant ruins in Anuradhapura compared to the rest of other ruins. To think that this used to be among the tallest building in the world back back baaaack then, it just simply put us in awe. Note that visitors need to remove their shoes or sandals to enter the area, so if you barefoot during hot sunny day, the walk will become very painful. No joke! So don't forget to bring and wear socks. The stupa itself is not hollow so there's nothing else to do there other than walking around and observing the stupa with fascination.

During 3rd cen BC, Jetawanaramaya had been the the world's third tallest building in the world. It has now been discovered that the Stupa is built on a square-shaped brick structure which is 26 m below ground level! Truly a marvelous structure!

This was the first site in Anuradhapura that we were taken to by our driver/guide and we were very impressed. To think that this 'building' pre-dates Christianity puts it, to my mind, alongside the pyramids in Egypt. OK there is not a great deal to do here except wander round but it is truly amazing. Additionally we were treated to the company of several coachloads of Sri Lankan children visiting at the same time as us. They were delightful and seemed to be fascinated by our fair skins and hair ( our driver suspected that they had come from remote village schools and not familiar with Westerners) and wanted to be photographed with us. This was a worthwhile visit for us. I would also like to put an alternative viewpoint to those posters who complain about the cost of entry to Anuradapura. The cost at around 3500 rupees is under UK¬£20, less than you would pay for a decent evening meal and this is for the whole city site which I doubt could be visited in full in one whole day. It is an historic site of world importance which housed an amazingly sophisticated civilisation pre-dating the birth of Christ. That it is not better known is surprising. As for the fact that locals pay a lesser entry fee (and this applies to sites throughout Sri Lanka and in some shops and restaurants too), I grant that this is an unusual arrangement but I personally do not begrudge them. We Westerners have probably spent more on our trip than the average Sri Lankan earns in a year. Third World country residents need all the help they can in improving their lot

A not so well known fact is that Jethawanaramaya was the 3rd tallest structure in the world (after the great pyramids of Giza) up until 800 or so years ago, and while not the tallest stupa in the world anymore it still is the largest in volume, and supposedly 90 million baked bricks went into making it. And when you're there, it shows; the base of the stupa is VAST, and even without two thirds of the top of the structure it still casts and imposing figure. It truly is a marvelous feat of human engineering!

All old Anuradhapura are in ruins. If you are Budhist, go and see them, if you are an archeologist, go and see them, if you are a simple turist, go to Polonnaruwa or better to Sigiriya or Dambulla. Too much ruins, but the old main stupa is beautifull, maybe not for 25 dollars. The new stupa is olso nice. Finally 2 stupas against lot of ruins - average.

This is the most impressive place in Anuradhapura - I would place it on top with Mihintale in "places to see in Anuradhapura". The stupa is the largest in the world, and overwhelms you with its size and symmetry. If you want to walk around the stupa, please choose early morning, or wear socks. The stone floor gets quite hot for bare feet.

so far this is the largest Stupa I have seen..its visible from quiet a distance from Anurathapura.. the Stupa shows how big the capital must have been and how rich was the state during Jethawanaramaya's time.. we loved it also because it was the first Stupa so large we saw for the first time and from where we started our tour to this rich old city of Anuradhapura which is also famous for their Moon Stone and Guard Stone..

This Stupa in Anuradhapura area is huge. You need to remove shoes to enter the temple, but the artwork inside is fantastic.  Fees were paid at the museum by our travel guide. You need your pass to travel around Anuradhapura. Be warned it is a vast area and the museum is the only place where you get the pass, so visit museum first.

Guys! All these places are completely Free of charge! For foreigners too! This is just a scam they are doing in this city. When we arrived our Taxi driver told us that we need to pay more than 3 thousand to go in these places, and showed a ticket. We believed him and decided not to go there, since it was so expensive. But later, when we were walking near it, we didn't see any tickets offices or anything like that. We asked security guards there, but they all said it was Free!!! So please, don't pay any money when you go there!
This is also a great stupa with ancient carvings scattered around the premises. Keep in mind you need to remove shoes so the best times to visit are early morning or late evening.

Since we were staying three days near Dambulla we decided to visit Anuradhapura since it was a World Heritage Site. Frankly, compared to Polonowarra, there is not that much interesting to see here to justify such high entrance price. The large stuba and renovated baths are interesting but after that you have to travel large distances to see things that in my ignorance were not that interesting. On the other hand you do not need to pay the entrance fee if you just want to visit the lovely Buddist temple and the tree of knowledge

3250 bucks for visiting places in Anuradhapura. 1625 for Asians. Too pricey for the so called attractions. This is just a place of working for Sri Lankans. There are so many Dagobas and Stupas in Sri Lanka that this doesn't feel special in any way. Just a place to visit since you're already here and paid for your hotel.

Most of the Sri Lankan sites that we've visited are expensive.  The locals get a much lower rate and foreigners pay whatever they can get away with.  This dagoba is no different... I liked this dagoba more than the others because not a lot of people are here to worship.  I feel like intruding on others pilgrimage when when they are all around you, praying. At JS, I was able to linger, take pictures, and look at the site instead of people. If this site wasn't so expensive, I'd rate it excellent.

The area is nice, no doubt about it. But entrance fee is insane. 3250 rupees each, and after seeing three sights they started to feel the same. That price does not include a map or any information about the area so we had no idea what we were looking at until we went home and googled it. Hired a tuk tuk driver to take us around, he was friendly and helpful but it added another 1500 rupees to our bill by the end of the day. Also, my wife was hassled at the entrance of two stupas because the back of her neck was showing in her modest dress, this infuriated her because local women were obviously showing far more skin and left alone. We are seasoned travelers that understand the dress code in religious places, but being blonde seemed to be innapropriate here. My wife was almost reduced to tears. Overall, this expensive and uncomfortable day was not enjoyable for us. Maybe history buffs would get more out of it then we did.

A visit to see the Jetawanaramaya Stupa is a must if you visit Anuradhapura. It is the biggest Stupa in Sri Lanka and its quite unique from the other Stupa's since it is still in its original brick form - not plastered in white.

At the time of its creation, this was the third largest structure in the world (after the pyramids) but even today, its scale is impressive. This was definitely my favourite part of my trip to Anuradhapura. It's one of two steps with exposed red brick and the result is quite different from the traditional Buddhist stupas. Try visiting near sunset for a more vibrant view. Don't forget the ticket to the ancient ruins. It can be purchased at the Abaghiriya museum. The price is steep at 3250LKR but the money goes towards maintaining these UNESCO cultural heritage sites.

We were there and had visited the sacred city with Jethawanaramaya Stupa and the museum and the Abhayagiri Stupa with museum.The museums were not really impressing, because there is not much explained on the antiques and they were really small museums.But i can recommend the `gold fish park`where you can have a really nice walk and it`s free of any entrance fee.Next to the park is the big reservoir called `Tissa Wewa`.

This is just like any other buddhist stupa only probably huger than the rest. The entrance fee is too high LKR 3250 per person. SAARC nations get it at half that price, but it is still expensive. When you buy the ticket, you get entrace to about 7-8 religious places, but all are alike. There are either brick stupas or white ones. The same kind of ponds with garbage strewn in the sides. The guardian stone and the moonstone also aren't anything great. You need to remove your footwear to visit these temples. I don't have a problem with that. It is religious. The only problem was the stone heats up too quickly and it was like walking on burning coal. Something needs to be done for this. By the end of the tour, we were less interested in seeing the monuments and more interested in finding shade for our feet. The museum has random pieces of pottery, jewellery and statues. Some are from India and other countries. All in all, I did not find it worth the price of the entrance ticket. And if you are from India, it is not too different from the local ruins we find in Hampi, Halebeedu etc.

Another impressive dagaba, this time with the bricks exposed. It is located away from the main pilgrim site. Even so it attracts the masses at religious festivals. The small museum displays the finds made from around this structure
A perfect dagoba , build long time ago ...perfect design and esthetic result is top ....move around don't forget to go according a clockwise way .

They say that you can build a three metres high wall from London to Edinburgh with the bricks that were used to build this Dagoba. Pretty impressive. And could you please use some of the massive entree fees(US$ 25)  to Anuradhapura historical site to clean up all the litter. Would show as much respect for these holu sites as taking of your shoes.
A really impressive piece of historic architecture. Absolutely put this on your list of places to visit whilst exploring the ruins and historic sites of Anuradhapura.

Another very famous historical site in Anurahapura and the Jethawanarama Stupa was built by King Mahasena in the Anuradhapura history. The stupa is built out of rock and is very tall. Well worth a visit.
Like most of the Dagobas it is large with a small shrine. Very much a recommend to those Buddhists. As a simple tourist I enjoyed it but wasn't spectacular.

When you stand next to it  (400ft) , you will realise how big it really is ! When it was originaly built it was the 3rd tallest monument in the world next to the pyramids of Egypt .  It is supposedly the tallest brick structure in the world (93.3 Million bricks have been used). Definitely worth a visit, kids had fun trying to figure out how tall it was by standing next to it !
This Stupa might be nice in case you haven't visited Myanmar - but after visiting Myanmar with all the great Stupas - this one is below average.

Strongly recommend this sacred sight. The best option is to hire a tuk tuk driver with knowledge of the area to drive you around. Start early to avoid the heat and possible afternoon rain. There is so much to see and experience. Just wander around the ruins and cast yourself back 2000 years and imagine the monks living in this beautiful place. The peace and tranquility is tangible and inspiring. The park like surroundings with these spiritual ruins is well worth the high entrance fee ($25). Don't rush - enjoy

Let me first preface by saying Anuradhapura is a long distance to travel from the main coastal resorts and so you should probably only consider if you are touring the island.  It was about a two hour drive from Sigiriya.  The area is too big to cover on foot in a single day and, whilst bicycles and TukTuks are easy and cheap to hire, I would recommend a driver/guide who can direct you to and provide commentary on the most significant sites. The four main stupas (Jethawanaramaya/Jethavanarama, Rutwanwelisaya, Thuparama and Abhayaagiri) are all different.  You won‚Äôt need more than 10-15 minutes at each unless you want to stay to worship, We don‚Äôt think there is any entrance charge ‚Äì we weren‚Äôt asked for any money and there were no ticket checks. As for all temples, you must dress respectfully (legs and shoulders covered). You need to remove hats and shoes but you can wear socks which I would recommend as the stones underfoot can be hot and sharp. Of the four main stupas, we liked Jethawanaramaya/Jethavanarama the best.  At 400ft high with a 370ft diameter base on a 670ft square rock base, this is the largest stupa in Anuradpura  and one of the tallest brick structures in the world.  It was built in the 3rd century. The dome is unpainted. It was very quiet and tranquil. Once part of a huge monastery and you can see the ruins all around.  It is worth visiting the museum where you can see a good collection of guardstones and ancient jewellery.  There is a clean toilet here too. Rutwanwelisaya has a massive white painted dome. It is 180ft (used to be twice that).  It is surrounded by wall with over 300 elephant sculptures but almost all these are restored or replacements.  It can get busy with devotees coming to pray. Thuparama is the smallest and oldest of the main stupas in Anuradhapura (what you see is mainly reconstructed).  Its significance is that it is said to enshrine the collarbone of the Buddha and as such there are lots of pilgrims actively worshipping. A white dome surrounded by stone pillars which used to support a wooden cover. See separate review of Abhayaagiri.

First we would like to say what we think the Anuradhapura Sacred precinct is and what it isn't. It is not Angkor Wat. We met lots of people that were slightly disappointed because they were expecting Angkor Wat scaled temples. It is however very impressive in its own way, especially if you use your imagination to envision what was once there and that thousands of monks once roamed around here. Apart from the Stupa, only the foundations of the monasteries are left because the buildings were wooden structures and rotted away centuries ago. But the sheer size of the this complex and the other complexes makes it worth coming here. Details such as beautifully carved gnome like creatures, animals and Cobra Kings provide delicate finishing touches of the monuments.
This was our first and best of the day. It is massive structure which dwarfs you the closer you get. The kids enjoyed walking around

Very large structure, gradually decaying. Ruins on the west side are nice to walk through, and there is a small footbridge on the west side to enter from. This entry is much more scenic and relaxing than passing the touts on the east entrance!

Jethawana Stupa is huge. Its huge from along way away and its even bigger as you get closer. You can see it from Minihtale and everywhere in Anuradhapura! Its 80 m high and 220 m wide. You cant miss it and you will be drawn to it. Its so impressive, its a statement about the power of the religion which built it. I prefer to view it in the morning.
This is the tallest Brick structure in the world,its amazing how such monuments were built with  such great technology so many centuries ago.
This was built in the 3rd century and is quite large.  It has several small temples around it that contain various gods.  Nice stop on the trip.

Jethawana sthupa excavation could be the largest excavation done by man up to date. The height of the sthupa from the base rock foundation to the peak is 260ft which is higher than the pyramids of Egypt. The foundation is 670 ft by 670 ft at bedrock, which is twice the dimension of a soccer field.The depth of the excavation is 252ft which equal to a 25 story building. For any person who is interested in ruins of ancient periods or conservations of olden architecture , there is no better place than Jethawanarama sthupa excavation
We arrived at late afternoon, a timing when it was uncrowded and definitely cooler. Dusk spectacular.

As one of the tallest brick structures in the world this stupa is truly awe inspiring. We went here in the evening and it was far less busy than the other main temples in the city. Well worth a visit for all those who like history and to admire the marvels of the past.
